text: basic English grammar lesson 3 topic the
simple past tense
in part four we'll continue to practice
forming questions I'll also share some
pronunciation rules with you let's talk
a moment about who and what be careful
with the question words who in what you
can form questions about the subject or
the object so far we've practiced
forming and answering questions about
the object these questions have this
structure who or what Plus did our
helping verb plus the subject plus our
main verb in the form of a base verb
here are two model questions who did you
watch in the video what did Jennifer fry
in the first question who refers to
Jennifer the object of watch in the
second question what refers to an egg
the object of fry now let's look at
questions about the subject we still
begin with a question word who or what
we do not need a helping verb did we
simply put our main verb in the simple
past tense
here are two model questions who fried
the egg what smelled good the answer to
the first question is Jennifer the
answer to the second question is the
fried egg Jennifer and the fried egg are
subjects
exercise 3 put the words in the correct
order example each word in orange will
be used once right away I see the verbs
did and eat so I know that this is a
question about an object the question is
who did you eat lunch with yesterday
one use the pause button on your screen
if you need more time to do this
who cooked your dinner last night too
what did you eat for breakfast today
three what was your biggest meal
yesterday now go back and answer the
questions in this exercise note who are
whom when do we use these words who can
be used for a subject or an object whom
can only be used for an object it's
mainly used in formal English examples
who fried the egg who did Jennifer fry
the egg for the first question is about
the subject the second question is about
the object in the next two questions we
use home because we're asking only about
the object whom did Jennifer fry the egg
for for whom did Jennifer fry the egg by
using whom we automatically become more
formal some people believe that it's not
correct to end a question with a
preposition so for whom is considered
more correct by some when we form
questions with the verb to be the
structure is slightly different let's
look first at yes/no questions was
Jennifer in the kitchen were the
children hungry too
we begin with was or were then the
subject then the rest of the question
the short answers can be yes she was no
she wasn't
or yes they were no they weren't note
the contractions in the negative
now let's look at WH questions or
information questions first model who
was in the kitchen answer Jennifer was
second model why was she in the kitchen
answer she was there because she wanted
to eat both questions start with our
question word we do not need a helping
verb if did we simply use was or were
exercise for listen to the phone
conversation fill in the missing words
hello where were you you didn't answer
the phone right away I began to think
you weren't home I was down in the
basement
why were you in the basement all the
chairs were down there
I needed to carry them back upstairs
why would the chairs in the basement
John and I had a party last night and we
needed more space for dancing
oh how was the party who was there it
was a lot of fun there were about 15 of
us just some old friends and a few
neighbors
you
you
I'd like to add a note on pronunciation
in the simple past tense the regular IDI
ending can be pronounced three different
ways like T as an walked like D as in
loved and like D that adds an extra
syllable as in wanted so how do you know
which way to pronounce the IDI ending
pronounce the IDI ending asked after
voiceless consonants the following are
voiceless consonants followed by the IDI
ending laughed walked jumped kissed
finished watched please note that this
list of voiceless consonants is not
complete this is only a list to provide
examples pronounce the IDI ending as do
after voiced consonants and vowels the
following are voiced consonants goo
hugged changed woo called mmm planned
and longed who lived surprised the
following or vowel sounds followed by
the IDI ending shared played again this
list is not complete these are only
examples of voiced consonants and vowels
followed by the IDI ending pronounced
the IDI ending as an extra syllable
after the sounds T indeed for example
visited skated added needed can you
think of other examples
let's try an exercise watch listen and
repeat you are going to watch the video
of Jennifers late night snack again this
time you will hear statements describing
the events pay attention to the
pronunciation of the regular verbs in
the simple past tense listen and repeat
1 Jennifer opened the refrigerator
- Jennifer wanted to fry an egg three
Jennifer placed the butter and eggs on
the counter
for Jennifer turned on the burner
five Jennifer waited for the butter to
melt six Jennifer cracked the egg open
and fried it
seven Jennifer flipped the egg
eight Jennifer finished frying the egg
and ate it that's all for now thanks for
watching and happy studies
